newsitem.title: USA: U.S. fed cattle numbers seen well above year ago.
newsitem.headline: U.S. fed cattle numbers seen well above year ago.

text.p: The supply of fed cattle on major U.S. feedlots, as of July 1, appears to be well above a year earlier following much larger placements during June than a year ago, livestock analysts said.
The U.S. Department of Agriculture is due to issue its cattle-on-feed estimates on Friday at 1400 CDT/1900 GMT.

"It should show we've got pretty big cattle-on-feed numbers that we've got to work through for the next month and a half. I think that will put a cap on prices," said Don Roose, president of U.S. Commodities.
A Reuter survey of analysts' produced an average estimate for the number of cattle on feed in large lots in the leading seven states of 115.6 percent of a year ago.
"The report will confirm that we have large numbers to move through, whether its 115 or 117 percent," said Karl Skold, director of research at Frontier Risk Management.
June placements were estimated at an average 115.5 percent and June marketings at an average 104.0 percent.
"It continues to be a bit of distortion on the placement figure because year-ago was so low," said Tom Tippens, analyst with Professional Cattle Consultants.
Tippens, who put placements at 125.1 percent of a year ago, said the total would be only six or seven percent above the five-year average.
"Corn prices are declining sharply and that is encouraging placements," said Tom Morgan, president of Morgan Research Group.

Analysts continued to estimate seven-state numbers while building historical data on the new 12-state part of the report. USDA made revisions to its seven-state report and introduced a 12-state report in January 1996.
They noted the rise in marketings during June partly reflected one more slaughter day versus a year ago.
Roose of U.S. Commodities said a four percent rise would indicate that feedlots were current on marketings.
"We've been pretty aggressively killing cattle," he said.
